PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: A Modeling Synthesis of the Impacts of Tropical Forest Conversion on Carbon Fluxes and Storage, and on Nutrient Dynamics in Amazonia
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
A Modeling Synthesis of the Impacts of Tropical Forest Conversion on Carbon Fluxes and Storage, and on Nutrient Dynamics in Amazonia
Objectives
Our objectives are to quantify and improve our understanding of the changes in C storage, C exchange, and nutrient dynamics in response to human-induced environmental change in Amazфnia. We will address these goals using models of canopy gas-exchange and ecosystem biogeochemistry. These models will allow us to use existing information and information collected during the intensive field studies to generate regional extrapolations, thus creating linkages in LBA between the specific point studies and the remotely sensed data.
We will use a hierarchy of models to scale in space from point to region and in time from hours to decades.
1. At the finest scale we will employ a process-based multi-layer canopy, soil-plant-atmosphere model (SPA) that predicts hourly gross photosynthesis and transpiration. This model is parameterized with fine-scale measurements of canopy structure and meteorology, and can be tested against independently collected tower eddy covariance flux measurements. We will also develop a transect version of the model to generate predictions of gas exchange along an aircraft flight path. The transect runs will necessarily be parameterized with less detailed data, and will allow us to investigate the effects of any simplifying assumptions on model efficacy. 2. At the next coarser scale, we will use a simpler, aggregated model of daily whole-canopy carbon © fixation and transpiration. This model is derived wholly from the process-based model, capturing its aggregated behavior, while operating with daily input and at significantly higher computing speeds. This aggregated model serves two purposes. Firstly, it can be employed within a gridded GIS database, so that we can derive regional estimates of C and energy fluxes under specified land-use and climate change scenarios. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Validation and Evaluation of MODIS Data Products in the Large Scale Biosphere-Atmosphere Experiment in Amazonia (LBA)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Validation and Evaluation of MODIS Data Products in the Large Scale Biosphere-Atmosphere Experiment in Amazonia (LBA)
Objectives
The MODIS Instrument Land Science Team (MODLAND) proposes to provide, evaluate, and validate an array of standard data products as tools for moderate resolution land surface monitoring and ecology over Amazonia. The LBA experiment and sites will enable us to evaluate the quality and performance of our products in conjunction with in-situ measures of various ecological parameters. MODLAND will make available level 2 and level 3 gridded MODIS data products to the LBA-ECO Science Team so as to maximize data usefulness and evaluation by the broader scientific community. We plan on working over both LBA transects, encompassing dry and wet tropical forests, cerrado, and various classes of land use conversions.
Research Team Responsibilities
* Alfredo Huete: Spectral vegetation indices. * Chris Justice: fire and thermal anomalies. * Jan-Peter Muller: albedo and BRDF. * Ranga Myneni: leaf area index (LAI), fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (fAPAR). * Steve Running: net primary production (NPP) * Yosio Shimabukuro: biophysical products. * Alan Strahler: BRDF and albedo. * John Townshend: land cover and land cover change. * Eric Vermote, University of Maryland: atmospherically-corrected, surface reflectances. * Zhengming Wan, University of California, Santa Barbara: surface temperature.
The MODIS land discipline group is developing remote sensing algorithms for deriving time-series data products of various terrestrial geophysical parameters, useful to regional-scale ecological studies of Amazonia. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Integrating Coarse and Fine Resolution Satellite Data to Monitor Land Cover Change throughout Amazфnia
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Integrating Coarse and Fine Resolution Satellite Data to Monitor Land Cover Change throughout Amazфnia
This proposal addresses a key need to accurately monitor land cover change at repeated intervals throughout Amazфnia. Spatially-explicit data on land cover dynamics in response to land use change are essential to extrapolate process-level understanding of carbon, nutrient, and trace gas fluxes over the larger region. Currently, monitoring efforts to quantify land cover change based on analysis of Landsat data are time-consuming, laborious, and data-intensive. Estimates from different analyses often yield conflicting results, highlighting differences in land cover definitions and methodologies applied by various researchers.
We propose to collaborate with colleagues from the Brazilian National Institute for Space Research (INPE) to develop efficient, accurate, and repeatable methods for monitoring land cover dynamics throughout the region. The emphasis will be on integrating data from different sensors at multiple resolutions to apply methods that are as automated and practicable as possible. Specifically, we propose to:
1) develop and test a nested approach using coarse resolution (250-500m) MODIS data to identify locations undergoing land cover change and Landsat data for more detailed characterization and analysis of those identified locations. Very high resolution (1-4m) IKONOS data and in situ observations will be used to validate the results. Through a nested approach, we aim to reduce the amount of high resolution data requiring time consuming analysis without sacrificing wall-to-wall coverage of the entire region.
2) examine an alternative approach to describe land cover dynamics in terms of subpixel percentage tree cover to circumvent the definitional differences in terms such as ?forest?, ?nonforest?, ?degraded forest?, ?deforestation?, and ?regrowth.? Ruth DeFries-Bajpai ? University of Maryland (US-PI) Yosio Edemir Shimabukuro ? INPE - Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (SA-PI)
Estudos relacionados a modelagem atmosfйrica e do ciclo do carbono vem atribuindo crescente importвncia аs queimadas antrуpicas como fonte de carbono para a atmosfera e como um elemento fundamental contribuindo para a variabilidade inter-anual dos fluxos de carbono a partir da biosfera. Estimativas anteriores do carbono emitido a partir de queimadas estгo baseadas em dados de satйlite de baixa resoluзгo e nгo consideram os diferentes regimes de fogo associados ao uso da terra nem as variaзхes de biomassa na бrea representada por cada cйlula do modelo. Vбrios grupos se empenharam em estimar as emissхes a partir queimadas em escalas globais, utilizando para isso mйtodos baseados em dados de baixa resoluзгo e seus resultados variam por um fator de dois. Anбlises detalhadas destas duas бreas testes irгo permitir determinar as incertezas presentes nas estimativas baseadas em dados de baixa resoluзгo. As anбlises propostas permitirгo tambйm particionar as emissхes de carbono provenientes de diferentes atividades, i.e., conversгo de florestas versus manutenзгo de бreas previamente convertidas para pastagem ou plantaзгo de palmas. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Carbon Balance in Amazon Forests from Site to Region: Integrating Remote Sensing from Satellites and Aircraft with Ground-based Tower and Biometric Data
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Carbon Balance in Amazon Forests from Site to Region: Integrating Remote Sensing from Satellites and Aircraft with Ground-based Tower and Biometric Data
Humberto Ribeiro da Rocha ? IAG - Instituto de Astronomia, Geofнsica e Ciкncias Atmosfйricas (USP) (SA-PI) Scott Reid Saleska ? University of Arizona (US-PI)
Objective: to link remote-sensing indices to flux tower and forest plot datasets to derive empirical predictions and test models of carbon dynamics at large scales. We focus on:
1. indices of seasonal variation in driving variables (e.g. sunlight and precipitation), and in the response of key processes (e.g. carbon fluxes and foliar activity);
2. indices of forest structure and disturbance history such as canopy height, canopy gap-size distribution, and stocks of coarse wood debris; and,
3. a hypothesized relation between seasonality and structure.
We focus on seasonality because ecosystem response to seasonal forcing provides a window onto mechanisms that also control long-term responses, but recent work (Saleska et al., 2003; Goulden et al., 2004) shows that such mechanisms are still not well understood. We focus on forest structure (a correlate of disturbance history) because recent work (Moorcroft et al., 2001; Saleska et al., 2003) shows that although carbon balance is acutely sensitive to disturbance history, the distribution of forest disturbance states across larger scales is not well known.
Methods: (A) Satellite Remote Sensing: We will use 5+ years of data from MODIS, focusing on the Enhanced Vegetation Index, EVI (canopy greenness) and on Land Surface Water Index, LSWI (canopy water) to reveal seasonal patterns in foliar activity. (B) Integration of remote sensing with ground studies at eddy flux towers, including: (1) Flux data: We will use eddy flux data from 12 Amazonian towers which sample primary forest, transitional forest, and converted lands to calibrate MODIS indices to predict basin-wide GPP c

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Influкncia da Sazonalidade e do Uso da Terra na Dinвmica Espaзo-Temporal da Produtividade Primбria na Amazфnia Oriental
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: A Amazфnia atualmente й o foco das pesquisas relacionadas com as mudanзas globais. No Brasil, a grande contribuiзгo para o aumento do CO2 atmosfйrico й proveniente das mundanзas no uso da terra (70% da emissгo total). Diante das incertezas apontadas na literatura a respeito da produtividade do bioma amazфnico e as consequкncias que este pode sofrer devido as mudanзas climбticas e de uso da terra, este trabalho visa suprir a necessidade de anбlises regionais mais detalhadas para a bacia amazфnica. O objetivo geral da pesquisa й modelar o processo de fotossнntese bruta em um ecossistema florestal na regiгo do Alto Tapajуs-PA, para avaliar os efeitos das mudanзas de uso de terra e do aumento de CO2 atmosfйrico, considerando a variabilidade espacial e temporal (sazonal e interanual) das variбveis ambientais (solos, vegetaзгo, nitrogкnio foliar, нndice de бrea foliar, temperatura, pluviometria, irradiвncia). Para atingir os objetivos utilizaremos uma abordagem metodolуgica multi-escala considerando tйcnicas de sensoriamento remoto, integraзгo de dados em um sistema de informaзгo geogrбfica, e as rotinas da modelagem matemбtica. Com isso pretendemos gerar resultados que possibilitem a anбlise quantitativa da PPB na escala regional. Esses dados poderгo contribuir substancialmente para um maior conhecimento dos processos biolуgicos na Amazфnia, e dos efeitos das variaзхes climбticas e das mudanзas de uso da terra. Tais informaзхes sгo indispensбveis para o planejamento do manejo dos recursos naturais da regiгo.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Classificaзгo e monitoramento da cobertura vegetal e uso da terra utilizando dados do sensor MODIS
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Este projeto apresenta uma proposta metodolуgica para a classificaзгo e monitoramento dos ecossistemas floresta, cerrado e pantanal, e detecзгo de mudanзas devido a causas naturais e antrуpicas. Neste contexto, foi selecionada para бrea de estudo o Estado do Mato Grosso, uma regiгo que possui diversas formaзхes vegetais e vem sofrendo grandes mudanзas no uso e cobertura da terra, devido а entrada da agricultura e pecuбria nas regiхes de cerrado, bem como as atividades de desmatamento e queimadas na regiгo da Amazфnia legal, tanto por causas naturais quanto antrуpicas. Para isso, serгo utilizados dados do sensor MODIS ("Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer") adquiridos durante o ano de 2002. Este sensor foi escolhido por possuir caracterнsticas de resoluзгo espectral e espacial que possibilitam uma melhoria na qualidade dos estudos em escalas regional e global. Os objetivos gerais deste estudo sгo: 1) gerar um mapa de cobertura vegetal da regiгo em uma resoluзгo espacial intermediбria entre os mapas jб produzidos; 2) monitorar as mudanзas fenolуgicas da vegetaзгo; e 3) desenvolver uma metodologia de detecзгo de mudanзas no uso e cobertura da terra, devido a desmatamentos e queimadas. Para atingir esses objetivos, serгo adaptadas as metodologias desenvolvidas para a classificaзгo da cobertura vegetal utilizando dados do AVHRR ("Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer"), e para a detecзгo de mudanзas no uso e cobertura da terra. Dentre os resultados esperados, podemos citar a disponibilizaзгo de um mapa da cobertura vegetal do Estado do Mato Grosso e de uma metodologia para detecзгo de бreas desmatadas e avaliaзгo das бreas de queimadas, gerados a partir das informaзхes multiespectrais e multitemporais do sensor MODIS. Tais informaзхes sгo importantes como base para o planejamento e manejo dos recursos naturais da regiгo.

Estas mudanзas de origem antrуpica constituem a dinвmica de uso e cobertura da regiгo Amazфnica. Seus produtos propiciam uma melhor representatividade e acurбcia das variбveis e parвmetros essenciais а modelagem ambiental. MT, Machadinho D?Oeste ? RO e Sгo Gabriel da Cachoeira ? AM. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Uso de dados orbitais para determinar a бrea de fogo ativo e modelagem numйrica da injeзгo de gases traзos e aerossуis a partir da energia radiativa do fogo
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: A degradaзгo ambiental й um tema abordado em todas as instвncias da pesquisa cientнfica. As alteraзхes dos elementos naturais por prбticas exploratуrias relacionadas, em grande parte, com o uso e manejo da cobertura vegetal, causam alteraзхes significativas nas interaзхes fнsico-quнmicas e biolуgicas dos componentes da superfнcie terrestre e na composiзгo da atmosfera. Neste contexto, as queimadas atuam como um fator modificador do meio ambiente e desempenham um papel fundamental no ciclo biogeoquнmico mundial. A partir da reaзгo quнmica que ocorre no processo de combustгo, os compostos orgвnicos presentes na biomassa vegetal sгo restituнdos а atmosfera e ao solo de maneira cнclica, influenciando as variбveis ambientais locais e regionais. Desta forma, o presente projeto tem como objetivo principal originar mapas climatolуgicos de бrea de fogo ativo e suas possнveis integraзхes com os diferentes produtos orbitais disponнveis, assim como, modelar a injeзгo de gases traзos e aerossуis provenientes da queima de biomassa florestal a partir da relaзгo entre a fraзгo chamas e a potкncia radiativa do fogo (FRP) para a Amйrica do Sul. Consequentemente, as estimativas da бrea de fogo ativo, da energia convectiva e das emissхes de gases traзos e aerossуis provenientes das queimadas serгo incorporados ao modelo de emissгo Brazilian Biomass Burning Emission Model (3BEM). que fornecerб os dados de entrada para o modelo ambiental Coupled Chemistry-Aerosol-Tracer Transport model coupled to Brazilian Regional Atmospheric Modelling System (CCATT-BRAMS). O desempenho das simulaзхes serб avaliado atravйs de sua comparaзгo com os dados coletados nos experimentos do Large Scale Biosphere-Atmosphere Experiment in Amazфnia (LBA) Smoke, Aerosols, Clouds, rainfall, and Climate (SMOCC) e Radiation, Cloud, and Climate Interactions (RaCCI).

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Refining tropical fire predictions: a spatially explicit framework for analyzing, quantifying and forecast fire incidence in Amazonia
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: In this document we propose the implementation of a project aiming to develop scientific research in a priority area of the Science without Borders Program: Exact and Earth Sciences. The proposal has also some aspects of technological advances and innovation. Moreover, the scope of the proposal can also benefit another priority area of the program which is: Technologies for Prevention and Mitigation of Natural Disasters, in particular fires in Amazonia. The objective of the proposal is to create a new routine for predicting fire probabilities in Amazonia using information derived from satellite products and field data. Our method is based on weights-of-evidence statistics. It will take advantage of the wide range of freely available spatially-explicit products, on deforestation, degradation, land cover, fire incidence, rainfall, sea surface temperature, and novel understanding on the drivers of fire occurrence, to produce a method that is scientifically relevant for analysing and predicting fire patterns, but also relevant for policy applications for preventing and mitigating fire problem in Amazonia. This research will be developed by the Coordinator and Visiting Researcher with the support of a Post-Doctoral research fellow, a Doctoral student and collaborators from INPE.
